Node Diversity.blurb: Many independent operators reduce capture risk.

sections.why: Diverse node operators make censorship or coordinated failure less likely.
key: Different clients and geographies prevent single points of failure
challenges: Hardware cost for running full nodes

Censorship Resistance.blurb: Hard to block transactions or exclude users.

sections.why: Ensures anyone can submit transactions without gatekeepers.
key: Validators include valid transactions regardless of origin
Relies on distributed consensus rather than single operators

Fault Tolerance.blurb: No single point whose failure halts the network.

sections.why: Redundancy in participants keeps the system running despite outages.
key: Replication of data across many nodes

Edge vs Cloud.blurb: Favor local control over centralized hosting.

sections.why: Running nodes on personal hardware reduces reliance on major cloud providers.
examples: Mesh networks for local block propagation

Trade-offs.blurb: Latency, UX, and costs can rise with distribution.

sections.why: Decentralization introduces overhead that impacts performance and usability.
key: Designs must balance convenience and resilience

Cryptography Basics.blurb: Hashes, signatures, and Merkle proofs secure state.

sections.why: These primitives provide authentication, integrity, and tamper resistance for blockchain data.
key: Hashes link blocks and detect changes
Merkle proofs verify inclusion without full data

Key Management.blurb: Seed phrases, hardware wallets, MPC custody.

sections.why: Proper key management safeguards access to funds and identity.
key: Seed phrases back up private keys
Hardware wallets isolate keys from malware
MPC splits signing authority across parties
challenges: User errors causing loss of keys

Audits.blurb: Independent reviews to catch vulnerabilities early.

sections.why: Audits detect smart contract bugs before deployment.
key: Report findings with severity and fixes

sections.why: Bounties incentivize finding vulnerabilities before attackers.
key: Reports verified and patched before public

Attack Vectors.blurb: Reentrancy, price oracles, MEV, governance attacks.

sections.why: Understanding exploits helps design safer protocols.
key: Reentrancy drains funds through recursive calls

sections.why: They enable portable, self-owned identities verified by third parties.
key: DIDs are unique identifiers without centralized registry

sections.why: Minimizes data exposure while establishing trust.
key: Zero-knowledge proofs reveal only needed facts

Zero-Knowledge.blurb: ZKPs enable private yet verifiable statements.

sections.why: ZK proofs allow verifying computation without revealing inputs.

Reputation Graphs.blurb: On-chain history and attestations signal trust.

sections.why: Reputation data helps apps evaluate reliability of participants.
key: Used for credit scoring and moderation

UX of Keys.blurb: Recovery, social guardians, and account abstraction.

sections.why: Improving key UX reduces user loss and boosts adoption.
key: Multi-factor flows balance security with convenience

sections.why: Voting mechanisms define how collective decisions are made.
key: Conviction voting accumulates support over time

Delegation.blurb: Elect stewards to scale decisions and expertise.

sections.why: Delegation enables governance by representatives for efficiency.
key: Token holders assign voting power to delegates
Delegates act transparently on behalf of others

Constitution.blurb: Rules of change and conflict resolution on-chain.

sections.why: Explicit constitutions define governance scope and amendment processes.
challenges: Hard to adapt to unforeseen events

sections.why: Securing treasury assets protects community funds.

Participation.blurb: Incentives and rituals that keep members engaged.

sections.why: Active participation ensures legitimacy and diverse input.
key: Regular calls and forums build community

sections.why: Bridges connect isolated ecosystems for liquidity and data transfer.
key: Relayers or validators verify cross-chain events

Standards.blurb: Common token and contract interfaces reduce friction.

sections.why: Shared standards enable composability across protocols.
key: Interface IDs allow detection and compatibility

Shared Security.blurb: Consumer chains borrow security from a hub.

sections.why: Shared security allows new chains to leverage established validator sets.
key: Hub provides validator set and staking

sections.why: Users interact with multiple chains through unified interfaces.
Interoperability introduces new security and economic vulnerabilities.

Layer-1 Blockchains: Guarantee that block data is retrievable.
Economic or probabilistic guarantees of permanence.
Fee, staking, governance use for native token.
Layer-2 Scalability: Assume validity; fraud proofs challenge bad blocks.
Validity proofs ensure correctness without re-execution.
Peer sets transact off-chain, settle periodically.
Fair ordering and reduced MEV on L2s.
Fast exits, liquidity providers, security caveats.

PoS Staking.blurb: Validators bond tokens and get slashed for faults.

sections.why: Proof-of-stake secures networks with economic penalties instead of energy use.
Choosing who creates the next block impacts fairness and security.
key: VRFs provide unpredictable yet verifiable randomness
Weighted schemes account for stake or reputation

sections.why: Additional layers provide faster or stronger guarantees of finality.
key: Overlay on base consensus to finalize blocks

sections.why: Networks need a way to limit pseudonymous identities from overwhelming systems.

Incentive Design.blurb: Rewards and penalties align honest behavior.

sections.why: Economic incentives ensure participants follow the protocol rules.
key: Game theory models analyze rational choices

IPFS Basics.blurb: Content addressing with hashes, not locations.

sections.why: Retrieving files by their hash creates a tamper-evident, decentralized web where data persists across peers.
key: Content identifiers (CIDs) address data by hash
Distributed hash tables locate peers storing content
Bitswap protocol exchanges blocks between nodes
challenges: Data can disappear unless pinned or incentivized
Mutable naming via IPNS is slower and less adopted

Filecoin/Economics.blurb: Markets that pay for durable storage.

sections.why: Allows phones and browsers to verify chain state without running a full node.
key: Download only block headers or proofs
Use SPV or zero-knowledge proofs for verification
Ideal for wallets and cross-chain bridges
challenges: Depends on honest majority for data availability
Less resilient to eclipsing or partition attacks

sections.why: Executing independent transactions in parallel boosts throughput and reduces latency.
challenges: Tooling and debugging for concurrent contracts

Price Feeds.blurb: Reliable asset prices for DeFi protocols.

sections.why: Many dApps need unpredictable numbers that on-chain logic alone cannot provide.
challenges: Costs for generating and verifying proofs

sections.why: Users can authorize token allowances with a signed message instead of an on-chain transaction.
key: Signature includes spender, value, nonce, and deadline
Improves UX for meta-transactions and paymasters
Widely adopted by tokens like DAI and USDC
challenges: Requires wallets to support signing structured data

Verification & Testing: Generate random inputs to find edge cases.
Circuit breakers, pause switches, rate limits.
Upgradeability & Patterns: Separate logic and storage for upgrades.
Safely move funds/state to new versions.
Fungible Tokens: Pay fees, access services, or reward usage.
Pools enable trading and price discovery.
Stablecoins: Supply rules target a peg (high risk).
Incentives & Game Theory: Lock tokens for yield and security.

DEXs.blurb: AMMs and order books for swaps.

sections.why: Decentralized exchanges allow peer-to-peer trading without custodians.
On-chain lending allows capital efficiency without intermediaries.
key: Collateral backs loans to manage risk
Interest rates adjust via supply and demand

sections.why: Derivative markets provide hedging and speculation tools in DeFi.
Automated strategies help users optimize yield and diversify portfolios.
Managing risk is essential to protect users and protocols in DeFi.
key: Insurance pools cover smart contract failures

sections.why: Handles tied to wallets enable cross-app identity without siloed accounts.
Open graphs let users port relationships across apps.
key: Followers stored on-chain or in open databases

sections.why: Direct payments and token models give creators new income streams.
key: Tokens or NFTs grant access or ownership
Fans can tip directly from wallets

sections.why: Community-driven moderation keeps networks healthy without central control.

Interoperable Feeds.blurb: Multiple apps over the same graph.

sections.why: Shared social graphs let many clients display the same content.
challenges: Spam and rate limits across networks

sections.why: Ownership enables secondary markets and persistence beyond a single game.
challenges: Risk of asset theft or hacks

sections.why: Well-tuned economies keep games fun and sustainable.
Shared standards allow items to travel between virtual worlds.
Combining off-chain gameplay with on-chain ownership improves performance.
examples: Gods Unchained matches off-chain, cards on-chain

sections.why: Cryptographic guarantees prevent cheating in competitive games.
Immutable provenance deters counterfeits and improves accountability.
key: Audit trail visible to all parties
challenges: Linking physical goods to digital records

sections.why: Tokenization unlocks liquidity and fractional ownership for real-world assets.
key: Smart contracts manage ownership and transfers

sections.why: Permissioned rails restrict access to verified entities.
key: Addresses added to whitelist via credentials

sections.why: Reliable data feeds link physical processes with smart contracts.
Simultaneous exchange of assets reduces counterparty risk.
key: Smart contracts escrow assets and payment
Transfers finalize in a single transaction
challenges: Regulatory acceptance of smart contract settlement

sections.why: Meet legal requirements to deter illicit finance.
Regulations mandate information transfer for certain crypto transactions.
key: Protocols transmit sender and recipient data

sections.why: Operating services often requires regulatory approval.
Users must report taxable events and track basis.
key: Trades and spending create tax obligations

sections.why: Evolving policies influence Web3 innovation.
key: Rules for DeFi and DAOs are emerging
